awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:(RAPID) Hazardous Hydrocarbon Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will provide currently uncollectable
temporal contamination measurements of hydrocarbons in response to the Deepwater
Horizon oil spill. The US EPA measures an array of hydrocarbons, providing feedback
to residents after a seven day delay. These compounds, known together as BTEX
(benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and total xylenes), greatly increase the overall
potency of petroleum, amplifying the effect of small contamination levels.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In response to the Deepwater Horizon event, the US EPA monitored Gulf Coast water for polyaromatic hydrocarbons, providing feedback to residents after a several day delay. Using existing technology, the EPA was simply unable to collect and test samples more quickly, resulting in week-old data of limited use for daily decisions. Moreover, a key subset of these monitored hydrocarbons (benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and total xylenes) indicates significant health and environmental risk. These compounds, known together as BTEX, greatly increase the overall potency of petroleum. It is assumed these volatile organic compounds (VOCs) evaporate before reaching shore, a questionable assumption considering the risks involved. Unknown factors such as changes in weather patterns, water currents, or daily temperature cycles can affect the evaporation rate on a transient basis. Only real-time testing can provide insight into the presence of these toxic materials. Our detection of BTEX, even on the short-time basis presented here, indicates the potential for more environmental and health damage than currently believed.

OndaVia is developing field-ready instrumentation to test water for various trace contaminants such as VOCs. The approved VOC testing methods couple separation with detection. OndaVia’s system leverages a similar approach, with microfluidic separation followed by surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy. OndaVia’s technology moves this concept into a single chip solution, providing separation and detection on a single cartridge that interfaces with commercially-available Raman spectrometers.

We monitored BTEX contamination along the Gulf Coast over a 24-hour period with two analysis systems and associated cartridges designed for part-per-billion detection. The OndaVia team analyzed samples from four locations, one each in Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, and Louisiana, at hourly intervals over 24-hour periods. The first trip occurred in mid-November 2010, starting in Ft. Walton Beach, Florida. The beaches were generally quite clean with no signs of oil on-shore. Contractor activity was high in Orange Beach, Alabama. The second trip occurred in late February and early March 2011. The beaches remained clean except along Grande Isle, Louisiana, where oil was washing ashore. Discussions with local residents indicated that oil continues to wash on-shore, and there is disappointment in the lack of attention to the issue.

A powerful benefit of our technology is the reduced complexity and cost of testing. The laboratory samples were held at 4°C during shipping, requiring coolers and ice packs to maintain temperature. Moreover, each sample required over 1-L of water in four glass vials, resulting in significant weight. The sample coolers had to be shipped priority overnight to guarantee sample temperatures, at significant expense. In contrast, the OndaVia travel case contained two analysis instruments and nearly 200 test chips for immediate, on-site analysis for BTEX contamination.

Samples were also collected by the OndaVia team for analysis at certified laboratories, with results that indicate BTEX is present along Gulf Coast beaches. No contaminants were detected during the first trip. The water was completely free of PAHs and BTEX at the 0.1-ppb level. The second trip, however, yielded positive detection events. At 6AM on the morning of 27 February 2011, naphthalene appeared in the Alabama samples at approximately 0.1-ppb. The positive result continued over three tests in Alabama, and remained over five tests in Mississippi, lasting until midnight. The positive test in Alabama was concomitant with rainfall; a storm system moved along the Coast during the morning.
